Summary I received PhD in Materials Science and during my graduate studies, I took the challenge of understanding crystal growth and doping phenomenon in semiconductor nanocrystals using advanced synthetic methodologies and various experimental tools. Now in my post doctoral research, I aim at application of quantum dots in charge and energy storage devices. 
 
Experience in thin (monolayer thin) film deposition using high vacuum Atomic Layer Deposition technique. 
 
Experience in device fabrication (capacitors) using high k dielectric materials using ALD and their surface analysis by XPS, AES, X-ray Reflectivity and Ellipsometry. 
 
Expertise in colloidal synthesis of group II-VI high quality quantum dots and doping of transition metal ions to get highly emitting non toxic dots. 
 
Expertise in controlling the shape of nanostructures from dots to rods to sheets and self assembly if such high aspect ratio structures. 
 
Expertise in analyzing crystal growth of the nanocrystals and surface functionalization to meet different application needs.  
 
Expertise in self operating TEM, SEM, XPS, XRD, UV/Vis, Fluorescence spectroscopy, FTIR and NMR tools for characterization of the nanostructures. Experience Postdoctoral Research Scholar Stanford University August 2013  – Present (2 years 1 month) Stanford, California •	Application of Quantum dots in charge and energy storage devices in a collaboration project with HONDA. 
 
•	Microscopic analysis of the dots using STEM-EELS to understand their capability to store charges with HONDA. 
 
•	Collaborating a project with BASF in screening precursors for atomic layer deposition (ALD) of high k materials on Si substrates. 
 
•	In collaboration with SAMSUNG in a project for obtaining high performance from dielectric materials used in capacitors (DRAMS) deposited by ALD.

Summary My interests lie in the use of natural and engineered systems to mitigate the effects of non-point source pollutants. My past and current research examines use of stormwater bioretention systems to remove pollutants and the metabolism of trace organic pollutants in plants. 
 
I currently work at the National Science Foundation's Engineering Research Center for Re-Inventing the Nation's Urban Water infrastructure (ReNUWIt) at Stanford University.  
 
My research focus has been plant uptake and metabolism of trace organic contaminants. Additionally, my work involves capture of stormwater and pollutant removal prior to groundwater recharge to augment water supplies in the arid West. Summary I am an environmental biogeochemist studying the physical-chemical processes that govern the natural carbon cycle in soils. The focus of my work is the influence of reactive metal species on rate and extent of carbon cycling in soil ecosystems. This work uses experiments with isotopically-labeled (13C, 15N) organic substrates in dynamic laboratory systems and chemical imaging of the interfaces between soil microbes, organic matter and reactive mineral phases. 
 
Specialties: 
 
Scanning transmission x-ray microscopy, µ-FTIR spectroscopy, high-resolution mass spectrometry imaging (NanoSIMS), XANES spectroscopy, electron microscopy, application of microelectrodes and microsensors (pH, Eh, O2) in soils, BET-N2 SSA analysis. Her research interests are:  
•	Assembly of nanomaterials with nano-precision, e.g.: carbon nanotubes, graphene, nanowires, and nano-particles, for CMOS and NEMS applications. 
•	Advanced CMOS device fabrication, characterization and modeling, e.g.: carbon nanotube field-effect transistors (bottom-gated, lateral-gated and double-gated).  
•	Self-aligned NEMS device fabrication, characterization and modeling, e.g.:  
Carbon nanotube NEM switches for logic applications,  
Carbon nanotube tunable resonators for RF applications.  
 
She has rich clean room work experience, as well as solid background in CMOS and NEMS design, characterization and simulation.

Summary During my research at UC Davis, I developed an extensive understanding of the biology of homologous recombination and DNA repair, which can be applied towards (but not limited to) cancer biology and gene therapy. Homologous recombination is a complex and highly conserved process that involves the sequential processing of various DNA substrates by dozens of proteins. In humans, the recombination pathway is intimately entangled with DNA replication, the DNA damage response, DNA repair, cell cycle control, apoptosis and telomere maintenance. All of these pathways are implicated in cancer biology. 
 
In my current role at Stanford, I plan to study the mechanics of chromosome segregation and chromatin assembly, specifically with respect to a specialized region of chromatin called the centromere. 
 
Specialties: high-resolution fluorescence microscopy, microfluidics, optical trapping, DNA repair & recombination, chromosome biology, genomic instabilityl. Experience Postdoctoral Research Scholar Stanford University School of Medicine April 2014  – Present (1 year 5 months) Department of Biochemistry I am a Postdoctoral Scholar working in the Straight Lab in the Department of Biochemistry at Stanford University School of Medicine. Accurate chromosome segregation in eukaryotes requires the assembly and function of the centromere––a highly specialized region of chromatin that serves as the scaffold upon which the kinetochore is assembled. The centromere-kinetochore complex––composed of more than one hundred proteins bound to several megabases of DNA––attaches to the mitotic spindle and functions to sense, regulate and generate forces that drive chromosome segregation during cell division. Centromeres are essential components of eukaryotic chromosomes, and defects in centromere assembly and inheritance result in aneuploidy––a disease-associated state of improper chromosome dosage that causes developmental disorders such as Down’s syndrome and characterizes most human cancers.  
 
I plan to reconstitute centromeres and kinetochores within microfluidic devices for high-throughput experiments with single-molecule precision and resolution using a range of tools––molecular and physical––to dissect and probe centromere structure and function. In doing so, I hope to better understand the mechanics of assembly, what factors are important or dispensable and how native and aberrant centromere-kinetochore complexes respond to physical manipulation mimicking forces from cell division––all in the effort be better understand the etiology of human diseases arising from improper chromosome segregation. Postdoctoral Scientist, Department of Microbiology & Molecular Genetics UC Davis September 2011  –  March 2014  (2 years 7 months) Davis, CA I was a postdoctoral scientist working in the Kowalczykowski Lab in the Department of Microbiology at UC Davis. I used single-molecule biophysics to visualize and characterize the biochemical activities of the yeast helicase, Sgs1, which is the homologue of the human BLM protein. Genetic defects in BLM are associated with an anomalously high predisposition for developing sporadic cancers due to genomic instability caused by defects in DNA repair and homologous recombination pathways. I was particularly interested in how the biochemical activity of Sgs1 is regulated during DNA double strand break repair by accessory proteins, including Top3, Rmi1, RPA, Rad51, Mre11 and Xrs2. In addition to my work on Sgs1, I also collaborated with several scientists in our group to study the molecular mechanism of BRCA2 during homologous recombination-mediated DNA repair using "visual biochemical" techniques. Graduate Student Researcher UC Davis, Department of Microbiology November 2004  –  October 2011  (7 years) I used single-molecule biophysics to directly measure the nucleation and growth rate of RecA filament formation on SSB-coated ssDNA, a process that is facilitated by a class of proteins called mediators, which includes RecFOR in E. coli and BRCA2 in humans. Summary Excellent hands-on cleanroom experience with semiconductor processing equipments for more than 5 years during doctoral and post-doctoral research work.  
 
Designed and developed MEMS-based sensors including fabrication and characterization of Lab-on-chip sensors, Passive micromixers and electrochemical Point-of-care sensors. 
 
Microfabrication Expertise and characterization: photolithography, wet etching, dry etching techniques (RIE, DRIE), thin film deposition using sputtering, e-beam evaporation, electroplating and plasma bonding, Scanning electron microscopy (SEM), atomic force microscopy (AFM), Keithley semiconductor characterization system 4200 SCS with probe station, Focused Ion Beam (FIB), profilometry, ellipsometry, Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FTIR), electrochemical analysis using potentiostats, optical and fluorescence microscopy, CFD-ACE for simulations and AutoCAD for mask making. 
 
Engineering Management and Leadership: Root Cause Analysis, Systems Engineering, Project Risk & Opportunity Management, Parallel Thinking, Innovation Creativity & Engineering Design. Experience Postdoctoral Research Scholar Stanford University October 2013  – Present (1 year 11 months) Stanford Supri-B: Reservoir Simulation / Pore scale simulations for unconventional hydrocarbon resources / Digital Rock Physics Research Scientist CERN / IMFT December 2012  –  August 2013  (9 months) Toulouse This project is borned from a joint effort between IMFT (Institut de Mécanique des Fluides 
de Toulouse) and CERN (the European Organization for Nuclear Research) in the context of LHC magnet cryogenic cooling by liquid Helium. Its aim is to develop a code able to simulate the Helium superfluid (He II) flow motion and its interaction with the magnet cooling. All developments are performed on the OpenFOAM CFD platform. R&D engineer and PhD fellow Air Liquide November 2009  –  October 2012  (3 years) This thesis was a collaboration between the numerical simulation group at the R&D division of Air Liquide and the porous media group of Toulouse Fluid Mechanics Institute. I was in charge to develop 3D macroscale models to simulate two-phase flow and mass transfers in cryogenic distillation columns equipped with structured packings. I successfully defended my dissertation and I get my Ph.D on october 2012. My works have been awarded by the Toulouse University prize (Léopold Escande prize) and a Toulouse Academy of Sciences prize. 
 
More specifically, The main tasks were: 
* Theoretical development of a comprehensive macroscopic model using an upscaling methodology to simulate two-phase flow in structured packing including: a turbulent gas flow, a gravity liquid film flow, a multi-component mass transfer with phase change, large scale anisotropy induced by the geometry of the packings. 
 
* Programming of the model within the OpenFOAM CFD toolbox, 
 
* Evaluation of effective properties from pore-scale simulations (permeabilities, dispersion tensors, exchange coefficients...), 
 
* Comparison of the simulation results with experimental data. R&D engineer Air Liquide February 2008  –  October 2009  (1 year 9 months) I worked 18 months at Air Liquide Research Center (first as an intern, and then as a service provider) in the department studying gas separation processes based on adsorption phenomena (PSA, TSA, VPSA...). To improve the recovery and the productivity of its adsorption unit, as the hydrogen production plants, the company uses Phase Change Material in order to smooth thermal effects in the adsorption columns. I was involved in the development of new thermal models, their implementation in the in-house adsorption processes simulator and their validation by comparison with experiments.  
 
Beside, I carried out the daily maintenance, and performed simulations in interaction with the engineering teams that work on these processes.  
 
Key words: porous media, adsorption, PSA, phase change material, non-equilibrium, hydrogen production Engineer Internship Synchrotron SOLEIL June 2007  –  October 2007  (5 months) Paris Area, France Postdoctoral Research Scholar Stanford University October 2013  – Present (1 year 11 months) Stanford Supri-B: Reservoir Simulation / Pore scale simulations for unconventional hydrocarbon resources / Digital Rock Physics Postdoctoral Research Scholar Stanford University October 2013  – Present (1 year 11 months) Stanford Supri-B: Reservoir Simulation / Pore scale simulations for unconventional hydrocarbon resources / Digital Rock Physics Research Scientist CERN / IMFT December 2012  –  August 2013  (9 months) Toulouse This project is borned from a joint effort between IMFT (Institut de Mécanique des Fluides

Summary Chronic and incurable diseases affect approximately 133 million Americans, representing 40% of the total population of the country. Common diseases like cancer, diabetes, stroke, mental illness etc. are responsible for $1.3 trillion lost economic output annually. Can we fight back to improve the situation? Can we strengthen our economy through a healthier and efficient nation?  
 
I am a synthetic organic chemist. I am passionate about it as it provides me a broad platform and scope to discover drugs for many common and uncommon diseases. Vast application of organic chemistry creates an opportunity to explore interdisciplinary fields and I am excited to explore the unique opportunity organic chemistry gifts me everyday.  
 
Interests: Medicinal Chemistry, Process Chemistry, Small Molecule Drug Discovery.
